description: From French marabout, from Portuguese maraboto, marabuto, from Moroccan Arabic مْرَابِط‎ (mrabeṭ) (standard Arabic مُرَابِط‎ (murābiṭ, “soldier stationed in fortified outpost”)).

entries.meaning: A Muslim holy man or mystic, especially in parts of North Africa. [from 17th c.]
examples: one of their principal targets was the marabouts – or holy men and leaders of mystic orders – whom they accused both of corrupting the faith by their espousal of mysticism and of being the ‘domestic animals of colonialism’.

entries.meaning: The tomb or shrine of such a person. [from 19th c.]
